title: International Study of Biology and Positive Well-Being
abstractText: There is increasing evidence that happiness and other states of positive well-being are associated with longevity and reduced risk of physical illness.  Medical scientists are beginning to think that this is not simply because illness affects people’s well-being, but that positive psychological states may be protective.  This study will evaluate links between positive well-being and biological responses that contribute to favourable physical health risk.  Positive well-being will be measured using a new method developed by two of the co-investigators, the Day Reconstruction Method.  The biological measures being taken include the stress hormone cortisol and heart rate variability, an indicator of the function of the autonomic nervous system.  Measures are being obtained using lightweight portable equipment not in the laboratory, but in everyday life settings as people go about their usual activities.  An important aim of this study is to test the consistency of associations between positive well-being and biology in different cultural settings.  There is a pressing need to understand international variations in well-being, suffering, and quality of life, and the factors in people’s daily experience that contribute to these differences.  Data collection is therefore being carried out using the same protocol in England, the Netherlands, and Hungary.
